modules.description: Represents the result of a completed process, including its exit status and captured output streams. Provides a structured way to access standard output, standard error, and process termination status. Useful for inspecting the outcome of system command executions, especially in testing or scripting scenarios where output and exit codes must be validated.

This module defines a request structure with HTTP methods, URLs, headers, and bodies. It provides functions to construct requests, convert them into command-line arguments, and format them for output. Use this to build and manipulate HTTP requests programmatically or for debugging purposes.

This module defines a polymorphic error type for handling and reporting various failure scenarios in HTTP request processing. It includes constructors for invalid requests, process failures, response read errors, and general exceptions, along with a pretty-printing function for error diagnostics. Concrete use cases include error propagation in HTTP client operations and structured error reporting for failed network transactions.

This module formats and prints HTTP headers represented as a list of key-value pairs. It provides a `pp` function that outputs headers in a readable format to a given formatter. Use it to display header lists during debugging or logging HTTP requests and responses.

This module represents HTTP responses with structured data, including status code, headers, and body. It provides a function to format and print response data for debugging or logging purposes. Useful for inspecting the full details of an HTTP response in a readable format during development or error analysis.

This module defines an enumerated type representing HTTP methods, including standard and custom methods. It provides a function to pretty-print these method values using the Format module. Useful for handling and displaying HTTP request methods in web applications or APIs.

This module implements HTTP request execution and response handling with support for standard methods like GET, POST, and PUT. It works with structured types for requests, responses, headers, and errors, enabling programmatic interaction with HTTP services. Concrete use cases include sending authenticated API requests, capturing and inspecting HTTP responses, and handling redirects or custom headers in client-side web interactions.
